links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow

Sir Gawain and the Green Knight

Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field

The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Lost Road and Other Writings
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Notion Club Papers Part Two
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Tolkien's Legendarium: Essays on The History of Middle-earth
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{disambig-two|the poem about [[Ælfwine]]|poem with a similar name to the earlier version|''[[Nameless Land]]''}} {{Poem infobox | title=The Song of Ælfwine on seeing the uprising of Eärendil | other names=The Nameless Land,
Ælfwine's Song calling upon Eärendel,
The Song of Ælfwine (on seeing the uprising of Eärendel) | written=May [[1924]] | revised=August 1924, 1936 or 1936, 1950s{{CP|74}} | published=''[[Realities: An Anthology of Verse]]'',
''[[The Lost Road and Other Writings]]'',
''[[Tolkien's Legendarium: Essays on The History of Middle-earth]]'',
| subject=[[Ælfwine]], [[Eärendil]], [[Tol Eressëa]], [[Straight Road]] }} '''''The Song of Ælfwine on seeing the uprising of Eärendil''''' is a poem that was written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]].{{LR|P1III3}}, ''Note on the poem 'The Nameless Land' and its later form'', pp. 98-104 The poem was published in [[1987]] within ''[[The Lost Road and Other Writings]]''. Three of the five stanzas of the latest version were reprinted in [[David Bratman]]'s article "The Literary Value of ''The History of Middle-earth''" on pages 79–80 within ''[[Tolkien's Legendarium|Tolkien's Legendarium: Essays on The History of Middle-earth]]'' in [[2000]].{{webcite|author=|articleurl=http://www.tolkienbooks.net/php/details.php?reference=13320|articlename=Tolkien's Legendarium. 2000|dated=|website=Tolkienbooks.net|accessed=30 December 2011}} == Prose note of the last version == ''[[Ælfwine]] ([[Elf-friends|Elf-friend]]) was a seaman of [[England]] of old who, being driven out to sea from the coast of [[Íverin|Erin]] [ancient name of Ireland], passed into the deep waters of the [[Valinor|West]], and according to legend by some strange chance or grace found the '[[Straight Road|straight road]]' of the [[Elves|Elvenfolk]] and came at last to the [[Tol Eressëa|Isle of Eressëa]] in [[Undying Lands|Elvenhome]]. Or maybe, as some say, alone in the waters, hungry and athirst, he fell into a trance and was granted a vision of that isle as it once had been, ere a [[West-wind]] arose and drove him back to [[Middle-earth]]. Of no other man is it reported that he ever beheld Eressëa the fair. Ælfwine was never again able to rest for long on land, and sailed the western seas until his death. Some say that his ship was wrecked upon the west shores of Erin and there his body lies; others say that at the end of his life he went forth alone into the deeps again and never returned.'' :''It is reported that before he set out on his last voyage he spoke these verses: ::þus cwæð Ælfwine Wídlást Éadwines sunu: :::Fela bið on Westwegum werum uncúðra, :::wundra and wihta, wlitescéne land, :::eardgeard ælfa and ésa bliss. :::Lýt ænig wát hwylc his langoð síe :::þám þe eftsíðes eldo getwæfeð.{{SD|66}}, p. 244 ''There is many a thing in the west of the world unknown to men; marvels and strange beings, [a land lovely to look on,] the dwelling place of the Elves and the bliss of the [[Gods]]. Little doth any man know what longing is his whom old age cutteth off from return.'' == Background == === ''The Nameless Land'' === Tolkien first wrote '''''The Nameless Land''''' at a house on Darnley Road in Leeds in May of 1924.''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]'', p. 107 The poem was first published by the Swan Press; London, Gay and Hancock Ltd. in 1927 within ''[[Realities: An Anthology of Verse]]'' on pages 24 and 25. The poem was inspired by the medieval poem ''[[Pearl]]''. === ''The Song of Ælfwine (on seeing the uprising of Eärendel)'' === Sometime during the writing of ''[[The Lost Road]]'', Tolkien revised ''The Nameless Land'', changing the title of the poem to '''''Ælfwine's Song calling upon Eärendel''''' and again to '''''The Song of Ælfwine (on seeing the uprising of Eärendel)''''', an "Intermediate Version". === Further revisions === The “Intermediate Version” was followed by two more versions and then a final version which was written either in conjunction with ''[[The Notion Club Papers]]'' and the poem ''[[Imram]]'', or in the period after ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' was published. == See also == *''[[The Song of Eriol]]'' {{references}} {{poems}} [[Category:Poems in The History of The Lord of the Rings]]
